print_settings.Notes:: Tool chance script start

description.text: Bill Effing Murray! This is a dual extrusion print. I printed at .15 layer height and 30% infill

Resolution:

.15

Infill:

30

Notes:

For anyone using the flashforge creator pro and simplify3d, I use the following script to get much cleaner prints. Adds more time as it lets one side cool down upon tool change, but it's worth it. I printed in abs, so if you're printing in PLA you will have to adjust the temps.... Just go to process settings, scripts, tool change script and copy the following.

; Tool chance script start
G1 X120 Y-70 F4000 ; Move out of the way while it stabilises active tool temp.
{IF NEWTOOL=0}; RIGHT Extruder is active
{IF NEWTOOL=0}M104 S160 T1; Cool inactive extruder to 160c (T1)
{IF NEWTOOL=0}M104 S230 T0; Heat active extruder to 210c (T0).
{IF NEWTOOL=0}M133 T0; Stabilise T0 temperature
{IF NEWTOOL=1}; LEFT Extruder is active
{IF NEWTOOL=1}M104 S160 T0; Cool inactive extruder to 160c (T0)
{IF NEWTOOL=1}M104 S230 T1; Heat active extruder to 230c (T0).
{IF NEWTOOL=1}M133 T1; Stabilise T1 temperature
; Tool chance script end

You will need to install the side pieces onto the frame, however, as you can see in my pictures, the two half spheres lock into the indents on the frames, keeping it in place. It can be a little hard to get the side parts installed on the frame, but once you have it in it is very secure, and won't just fall out.

description.text: I had an idea to take those glasses that people wear to parties and make them halloween themed. Just so that everyone knows, these party glasses are not rated for dogs, but they are dog approved ; ). So, I created my Jack-O-Lantern Party Glasses. Now you can go in style to a halloween party sporting these halloween themed party glasses. I wanted to take my design to the next level, so I decided to also make them fold up just like any regular pair of glasses because as I was looking around Thingiverse I realized that not very many designs actually did that (most of them were just one solid shape). Not only that, but as you can see in the pictures they actually fold up quite nicely.This prints as two separate files. Printing is very easy, and everything snaps nicely together right off of the print bed. So be sure to print out a pair of the stylish Jack-O-Lantern party glasses before you head off to your halloween party.

Printer:

Flashforge Creator (Dual)

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

This is a very straightforward, easy print to do. You will need to install the side pieces onto the frame, however, as you can see in my pictures, the two half spheres lock into the indents on the frames, keeping it in place. It can be a little hard to get the side parts installed on the frame, but once you have it in it is very secure, and won't just fall out.

Simple rendering in Rhinoceros3D. Designing is Rhino

All I did to design this was I took a picture of a Jack-O-Lantern, and I traced out the vital parts in Rhino. I then used measurements that I got off of a pair of sunglasses, and used that to size these so that they would fit.

comments.text: A tip for other makers: these glasses print well, but they're rather big and heavy using the default settings. For my next attempt I'll shrink them a little and use as little material as possible. I think I'll try 10% smaller, 10% infill, 1 perimeter, and only 1 solid top and bottom layer.

title: Star Trek: Frontiers trays / box insert

description.text:
This is a set of trays for all of the pieces in the game Star Trek: Frontiers. They can be used to hold the pieces during play, as well as store them in the original box.

I designed them to strike a balance between storage space, ease of game setup, and usefulness during gameplay. They turned out fairly well; the card containers are a little snug if you sleeve your cards, but they seem to be working so far.

To stack the trays in the original box:

  • On the bottom layer, put the four player trays and the borg cube tray.
  • Put a piece of paper / cardstock over the player trays (otherwise, some of the trays in the top layer won't sit straight.)
  • On the top layer, but the encounter tokens over the borg cube tray. Put all of the other pieces on top of the player trays.
  • Put the manuals and advancement track on top.

I printed everything with 15% infill and no supports. My printer bed is 6"x10", so the files are sized accordingly. However, if you have a smaller print bed, there shouldn't be any problem with slicing the components up and gluing them together.

To hold all of the game pieces, you will need to print:

  • 4x player.stl - I printed these in colors that matched the player colors.
  • 2x borg.stl - I glued them together to make one long holder for all four cubes.
  • 2x encounter_tokens.stl - Similar to the borg cube holder, I glued them together.
  • 4x deck_22.5mm.stl - These are for the crew decks, rule cards, and turn order cards.
  • 3x deck_45mm.stl - These are for the advanced action, undiscovered, and damage decks. If you don't sleeve your cards, you can use 22.5mm deck holders for the advanced action and undiscovered decks.
  • 1x dice_and_tokens.stl
  • 1x data_crystals.stl
  • 1x map_tiles.stl

description.text:
I needed a light switch cover to keep the outside motion-sensor triggered lights powered without rewiring. I also wanted to be able to leave one side open for when you really do want to adjust the switch.

I found this one on the site: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:6688

I made it and it worked, but it's too thin on one side and I wanted to print it on glow-in-the-dark PLA so I could see switches when the lights were off & it didn't print well on PLA.

SO, I started from scratch and made my first Fusion 360 project. I've shared the STL and what I think are all of the Fusion files you'll need to recreate it. It turned out great - much more solid and it glows well.

For stability, I printed it with 100% infill, but it's probably not necessary.

author: rjm226

title: Dual Fillament Ball Guide Geeetech Prusa I3 pro C

description.text:
While technically not a remix, I did like 'Geeetech Prusa I3 X Ball filament guide by Rafaello, published Apr 29, 2016' ball filament guide. But I needed to have two spheres to guide the filament for my dual extruders. Special thanks for the inspiration!

If you print this, please post a picture on the 'I've made one'. Thanks!

I was thinking about coping their files but found that it contained too many continuously changing curves, not easy for a quick copy. So... I decided to create my own from scratch. It gave me more practice using Freecad which I can always use.

At first I made this as a single color print. Then I thought, "This is for dual filament extruders! What would be more fun than to print it with the dual extruders?" Having not used both extruders except to see that the second one worked (I'm still a newbie at this). I didn't know what I was getting into. But as it turned out - not too hard. And Yes, I would design two color prints again.

So now I had to learn how to create the two extruder files, have the extruder files align, and then print them. Remember this is after only printing someone else's file for dual extruder. The good news is I tried a few things and it worked! Let me know if you need some instructions on how I did it in Freecad.

Then on to the first print. Oh no, I found that my extruders were not calibrated close enough so the spheres became part of the base - they wouldn't move.

To get the first working print (which I am using now) I decreased the ball diameter to 8 mm. This allowed it to rotate freely. The only problem was it 'looks' loose. As the ball drops about 1 1/2 mm just sitting in the socket. But It works great and better than I hoped! Keeps the filament coming in 'straight' to the extruders.

So I designed a couple of calibration cubes (8mm, 8.4mm and 8.7mm balls) to test my setup. I found that I could go a little bigger on the spheres. Check out my Thingiverse posting for the test box with internal spheres.

I am now calibrating the extruders to see if it will print any better. I'm using 'Dual Extrusion Calibration using Slic3r by doctek, published Jul 28, 2013 ' Check it out if you need to calibrate the extruder offsets.

I didn't get the calibration perfect yet, but I was able to print out the dual filament holder with the 8.4 mm spheres. They broke free very easily and are working perfectly.

Printer:

Geeetech i3 pro c

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

30%

Every time I learn something new..... something else is not quite right.

And so it is with printing with dual extruders. I'm getting an oozing problem that imbeds the two colors on the edges of each other. Setting the retracting higher has helped, but I would like it better. If someone knows how to do a 'wipe' tower in Slic3r let me know.
Using Freecad. This item is fully parametric.

To print in one color just load both (Slic3r) and join as the same group, naming the same extruder. Other slicing programs probably have similar features.

If anyone is having trouble joining these as a single color file, let me know and I can generate it for you. (probably the 8.4 mm sphere would be best). But why would you do that if you have dual extruders? Also, if you want the freecad files I can also upload them.

The first picture is with the 8.4 mm spheres. The last (darker picture) is with the 8 mm spheres. Both have worked great for me.

description.text:
This heat cover is designed for X-ONE printer that has no heat cover as their upper model "Avatar IV".
Heat cover are constructed as 3 part.
Front panel.
Side panel.
Top cover.
Each part use 4mm thick transparent polycarbonate cardboard.
Cardboard connectors are used for top cover.
And plastic L angle bar has been used for each edge costume.

QIDI AvatarIV

PLA or ABS,
ABS is better for high temperature moisture on this usage.

For Front panel

Please use 2step part from X-One rib.stl
Using 4x M3 15mm screw at edge side.
Washer , Spring Nuts, And Nuts
Please adjust inside space

For Side panel

Please use 1step part from X-One rib.stl
Using 4x M3 15mm screw at edge side.
Washer , Spring Nuts, And Nuts
Please adjust inside space

For Top cover

Following parts are necessary.
2 corner.stl for rear upper .
2 edge_656c.stl for front slant upper.
4 bottom_corder.stl for bottom.
4 bottom_base.stl for place each corner of topside window.
supplemental parts
edge 656b.stl : It can use for top and slant line.
edge.stl : It can use for each edge that has right angle

This parts are designed as angle of slant 65.6degree.
Please confirm your PTFE tube height during printing.

Bottom_base parts are placed at each corner of topside window.
And temporary hold by tape etc.

After create whole of top cover then placed on bottom_base with bottom_corner as adhesive material. My bottom parts are created with ABS filament so ABS adhesive is necessary.
It is recommendation.

Each edge are costumed with plastic L angle bar.
for slant edge that has broad or sharp from right angle.
I have broken L angle on these area and taped from inside.
So you can get free joint Angle on this point.

For temporal build up , You can use strong adhesive tape.
And after that you should use normal plastic adhesive for those.

Let's enjoy.

description.text:
I wanted to provide a "guide" for the filament on my Anet A6 3D printer which prevented any restriction to the filament to minimize feeding issues.. I didn't want to use an "eyelet" type of guide, as it requires the spool to be in a specific location behind the printer (and I had other plans for that... forthcoming)

So I created a pair of brackets which mount to the top of the Anet A6 frame (pictured) through existing frame M3 screws. I ran a piece of aluminum (3/8" / 9.5mm) which I had around the house across the top... this allows the filament spool to be placed most anywhere, and allows complete freedom to the filament as the printer moves back and forth across the X axis. See pictures.

I've included the 123D file in case you need to modify the size of the hole for a different sized rod.

For a variant of this which also incorporates a Micro SD card reader, see my remix at http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1802502

comments.text:
Thanks for sharing.
There is definitely a point there, not forcing the filament inside a loop causing friction.
I will remix it soon, placing a printed guide above the display also adding an (open) arc, so that the filament can not hop off the rail.

title: Calibration test box with internal sphere - Dual extruder

description.text:
This is my test setup for checking if I could print these for my dual filament guide project.

If you print this, please post a picture on the 'I've made one'. Thanks!

Put three test boxes down then insert the different size spheres. Print three at a time and compare the results.
The box has a 9 mm radius sphere pocket. The spheres come in 3 sizes; 8 mm, 8.4 and 8.7.

The inner sphere should rotate 360 degrees on every axis when done.

The picture shows two different size spheres printed, the 8 mm and 8.4 mm inside the box. As you can see, the 8 mm sphere is a little looser than the 8.4 mm and it drops down farther in the box. The 8.7 mm sphere became part of the box and wouldn't come loose. Maybe further calibration and printed in a finer resolution would free it up.

I'm still working on getting the oozing under control. I haven't been able to get Slic3r to fix it yet.
Created in Freecad and is fully parametric

comments.text: I can't take credit for the idea, but it does show some of the fun you can have with dual extruders.  Glad you liked it.

remixed_from.title: HICTOP Prusa i3 Cable Chain mounts

title: Anet A8 I3 X-Axis Cable Chain Mounts

description.text:
This is a remix of the HICTOP Prusa i3 Cable Chain mounts. After doing the install on the x-axis, I discovered that the cable chain would rub the left x-axis threaded rod whenever the carriage moved to the left. This rubbing would cause the carriage to shake, and distort my prints.

My solution is to create new offset mounts that are set back about a centimeter on both the carriage and the motor. The clearance created by the offset is perfect for the Anet A8, and works smoothly.

Note: I guilt the carriage mount vertically in OpenSCAD, but you should rotate it 90 degress, and then use supports when you print it.

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Anet A8 I3

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1 Layer Height

Infill:

25% Lines

Installation

For the x-axis motor mount, you'll need an M2 screw at least 20mm long.

For the carriage mount, you'll need to remove two screws at the top of the carriage that are next to each other. The carriage mount can then be screwed into position using the two holes in the carriage and bearing. You may need longer screws to accomplish this.

To make a cable chain of an appropriate length, you'll need to print at least 30 links between the mounts.

comments.text: I'm cranking out the pi3 base now.  Next will be the Vesa panel.  I already have the tool bracket (non-vesa kind) and a couple of long allen drivers.  I suppose I'll wait and see how the vesa bracket and case turn out.  I've remixed the tool bracket pieces (made a microSD holder) so I'd be able to remix the bracket, if need-be.

Air Lift - Bubbler Pump - Optimized for use in an Aquaponics system as a Bubble Riser / Airlift Pump to increase head height.

To be used in conjunction with Tesla's Valvular Conduit

I have made the inlet point filled, so it can be drilled to the required hose gauge after printing.

This is a 20x20mm Calibration Cube - and its the best way to use the 20cm of filament you got with your Chinese Reprap clone from AliExpress. You can judge that your printer is printing correctly by measuring this, after printing, with a pair of callipers, or a ruler, or perhaps your pinky finger will do as a measuring device, seeing as your the cheap-ass with a $200 printer from AliExpress.

Introduction

This was an incredibly difficult task, took me over 40 hours, working non-stop from my bedroom, but guys - I did it.

Step 1

I pressed the on button on my PC. Although a relatively simple task to some, considering my circumstances, it was a huge barrier for me. First - I was a little tadpole in my Dad's tentacles. Na - I'm just messing with ya'll, I don't have the time to be that detailed. For lunch that day, I had a butter in white-bread sandwich, and by using my body's previously attained kinetic energy,

title: Microscope adapter for Apple iPhone 4 or 4s camera

description.text:
2-parts microscope adapter for iPhone 4 or 4s. Designed to fit classic zeiss ocular or any other with 24 to 28mm diameter. This adapter has been printed and tested on various microscopes.
Files are manifold. In some cases, you may need to adjust position between part 1 and part 2, so that the lenses are aligned.
The next iteration will make this step easier. P.S. : The iPhone featured above was not broken during testings ;) [UPDATES]
14/11/2013
  • Added STL file OcularSupport_V6.2_kpl_RDM.stl : suited for Zeiss KPL and other 27,8mm diameter (long barrel) oculars. This file has an oversized barrel holder to correct plastic retraction when printed with extruded plastic. You should use this file if you own a reprap.
  • Added pictures of the above new print (ABS) fully assembled with part 1 (iPhoneAdapter ) and a Zeiss KPL W16 ocular.
    • 11/11/2013
  • Added STL file support_V6_kpl.stl : this alternate ocular support is designed to fit Zeiss KPL oculars. It was printed in ABS, but doesn't take into consideration plastic retraction (about 5%). So the ocular holder may seem to tight when printed with a reprap.
  • Added pictures of the above new print (ABS)

Needed :
  • 3x M3 bolts
  • 3x M3 nuts
  • 1x M4 bolt
  • 1x (or 2) M4 nut.
    • Chose one of the 3 ocular support STL file and the iPhoneAdapter STL file. ABS appears better suited for this purpose, than PLA, considering the mechanical strains. Assemble iphone base and ocular support using the 3 M3 nuts. Tighten (slightly) the ocular with the M4 screw. You may need to counter-drill the screw holes. Be carefull about the ocular-iphone camera alignment. Custom alignment will be considered in the next version. IMPORTANT : supportobjectif_V5.STL and OcularSupport_V6.2_kpl_RDM.STL files take into account plastic retraction after cooling (about 5%). But support_V6_kpl.stl file doesn't. If you print the first V6_kpl file with a reprap, the ocular holder part may be too tight To do :
  • Sliding screws for adjusting part1-part2 position
  • iPhone bottom lock
  • Anti-warping design (on the V5 file)
  • Ocular holders for wide lenses and other brands/types

title: Printrbot Simple Metal Ubis 13s fan mount
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
A custom fan mount and ducting to suit an always on 40mm fan for the Ubis 13s cold end cooling.

This cooling set-up allows the whole cold end to be cooled, including the PEEK insulator unlike the fan shroud design by printrbot that only cools the aluminum heatsink.

Wiring for the fan is the same regardless of hotend so the link at the bottom for the e3d guide may help, otherwise if you have an ATX power supply, just use a molex fan connector.

All parts can be printed easily without support.

Requires 4x M2.5x20 bolts.

Fan should be wired as shown in this guide.

http://matterhackers.dozuki.com/Guide/How+to+Install+an+E3D+v6+HotEnd+on+a+Printrbot+Simple+Metal/9

comments.text: I have been having problems coming up with fan shrouds that work with my ubis 13s setup, for some reason my ubis 13s seems to be higher from the bed than most of the shroud designs allow for. Using your design in combination with http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1144522 gives me the clearance that I need. When using the short fan shroud the fan mounts on the side closest to the hotend.

comments.text: That's strange, my 13s is about 74mm long, figured all would be +/- 1mm. regardless, good to hear this works for you.

remixed_from.author: willnewton
remixed_from.title: MPCNC drag chain / cable carrier for XY-axis

description.text:
I took the blank version of the drag chain mount and put a hole in it to allow a camera to be mounted below the roller. Use a 1/4" bolt to mount a GoPro or regular camera below the roller. I mounted my iPhone using a smartphone mount (a Shoulderpod S1) attached below the roller.

After testing this, it's not very usable for video but definitely seems to lend itself to timelapse...plus, few people want to watch real time milling :)

You can see a comparison between realtime and timelapse video using an iPhone 6S+: https://youtu.be/aUu0kCvpkRk

comments.text: Simple, creative, and effective remix.  I like it!
comments.author: willnewton

comments.text: Thanks! And thanks for your very useful original design!

title: DIY Desktop Laser Cutter and Engraver - FABOOL Laser Mini

description.text:
FABOOL Laser Mini is an open-source, ready-to-assemble type of desktop laser cutter and engraver, which was developed by smartDIYs, a group of Japanese engineers.The machine excels in usability and expandability, which enables it to meet variety of needs.

It all began with developing a high-power 60W large laser cutter and engraver for our own a year and a half ago, we turned it into a smaller version of desktop laser cutter and engraver, as Smart Laser Mini. This time we are releasing the upgraded version as FABOOL Laser Mini, with improved usability, stylish design, and 1/4 of assembly time.

In June 2016, FABOOL Laser Mini, collected about $60 million , which was the highest amount ever in the history of major crowdfunding platforms in Japan as well as the second highest among laser cutter campaigns in the world.

To find out more about us: http://www.smartdiys.cc/fabool-laser-mini/

<Key Features>

  1. “Scalability” which adapts to various needs of users
    Extension of parts allows users to customize based on their needs. (e.g. Expanding the frame which leads to 1m*1m processing range, Replacing the laser head to one with can produce higher output). Because both hard and software are open source, it made possible to add User’s original functions.

  2. Satisfying a wide range of needs by providing sufficient machine performance
    Equipped with high-spec motor driver and high-speed microcomputer chip, FABOOL Laser Mini can be used in various situations from designing, to teaching, to prototyping, and more! Despite its affordability, the high-spec and good quality of Japan-design laser cutter will not disappoint users.

  3. Easy assembly
    Assembly only takes about two hours. All you need is hex wrench and spanner, which are included in FABOOL Laser Mini kit.

  4. User friendly cloud-based software
    The free all-in-one software, which is cloud-based and works on the browser, includes functions such as creating and retrieving the processed data of products - sharing all those data and images of the products among other users.

Manual

Step-by-step instruction manual for assembly and how to use the software.
http://www.smartdiys.cc/manual/fabool-laser-mini/

description.header: More Details of FABOOL Laser Mini
description.text:
Product Specification

Work Area: 300×230mm
Laser: 1.6W Laser Diode 445nm (Basic Model) / 3.5W (Power-up Model)
Supported Processing Method: Vector engraving, Raster engraving
Supported OS: Windows7, Windows8, Windows8.1, Windows10, Mac OS X, Linux, Raspberry Pi
Supported Browser: Chrome、FireFox
Supported File: SVG、DXF、JPEG、BMP、PNG、TIF、GIF、PSD
Accessories: USB Cable, AC Adapter, Laser Safety Glasses, Hexagon Wrench, Spanner
Power Supply: AC100V-240V
Size: 540×485×140mm(Not including cable)
Operating temperature: Below 30℃ (86F)
Continuous operating time: Under one hour
Weight: About ４kg

-- 1.6W Laser Diode
Blue Laser Diode 1.6 W in TO56 Package by OSRAM Ltd.
-- 3.5W Laser Diode
Blue Laser Diode 3.5 W by NICHIA Cooperation.

-- Mechanical parts
We adopted open builds V-slot (http://openbuildspartstore.com/) for our mechanical parts, which leads to simple and easy assembly.

-- Computer software
Computer software works on the Browser. It’s made by HTML, JavaScript, Python. Also it’s Cross-platform, and you can use it with Windows、Max OS X、Linux、Raspberry Pi.

-- Software Download
Instruction for downloading the software:
http://www.smartdiys.cc/manual/fabool-laser-mini-install-softwe/

-- Control board
The control board uses STM32 microcontroller.
Microcontroller’s program is based on GRBL (Bengler: GRBL)
FABOOL Laser Mini Shield designed using the KiCad.
KiCad EDA
Download FABOOL Laser Mini Shield’s design data file from GitHub.
・KiCad data files
・Circuit diagram (pdf)
・Parts list
smartDIYs/SmartLaserMiniShield · GitHub

-- Work with Raspberry Pi
FABOOL Laser Mini also works with Raspberry Pi.

-- Motors
Use 3pcs of NEMA17 Stepping motors(JK43HS34)

-- Processing method
Vector Method
The vector method can cut along the outer shapes also It can be created in SVG or DXF format.
Raster Method　
Raster method is for impressing an image while horizontally scanning just like filling.
Raster method can be put with SVG, PNG or BMP format images.

-- Open source
Visit our official website for open-source data regarding PCB, mechanical design, and driver software.
http://www.smartdiys.cc/manual/open-source/

Expansion Kit allows to expand the cutting bed to 1m*1m. Assemble only takes about two hours on average. All parts required to assemble FABOOL Laser Mini.

remixed_from.author: cmniemann
remixed_from.title: Monoprice Select Mini 3D Filament Feed Base

title: Monoprice Select Mini 3D Filament Feed Base Remix

description.text:
Remix of the Filament Feed Base for the Monoprice Select Mini 3D Printer. The feed base broke near one of the screw holes on my Monoprice Select Mini and I tried using the model released by cmniemann, but it did not work with my printer do to several alignment issues (most notably the spring mount). This is my mod on the original so it would work with my printer without issue. Thanks go to cmniemann for the original design.

I printed this with supports, not sure if you can get by without them (I never tried).

Changes from the original:

  • raised spring mount to be equal to lever position (original caused misalignment between filament bearing and the extruder gear)
  • moved screw hole closest to base's spring mount a little to right to better align with hole on top of printer (was difficult to insert screw), screw head stop was also lowered to give better clearance with lever arm
  • reduced size of added "bumper" on left side to aid with above hole clearance
  • better clearance around the geared drive
  • added small divot on lower right side for better clearance around filament feed tube
  • extended support around filament hole for cleaner 3D prints
  • added extra support around the outside of the screw mounts

Update 2016-Sep-22

Added "Feed_Base_Remix_v05.stl" which contains all fixes present in the previous versions. I've printed it and it is what I'm using on my printer now as a replacement. As v05 appears to work without any major issues, I've removed the preceding versions.

title: Adjustable Belt Tensioner/Tightener and Belt Tie (Tevo Tarantula)

description.text:
A simple, adjustable belt tensioner + a belt tie to replace the cable tie.
The tensioner requires an M3 screw. The screw hole is tight-fit and should provide more than enough tension to hold the screw. Designed to be printed at 100% scale.

Use higher wall line count (shells) & high infill for maximum strength.

The calibration cube in 3rd photo was printed @0.1mm layer height with properly tensioned belts and a Dual Z mod https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2163949

sketchup/fusion360 file is attached in case adjustment is needed.

Update 3/11/17 : New hole, added fillet.
Update 10/23/16 : increased thickness for screw holder and legs.

This thing is the handle cap or screw that covers the unused
one of the handle holes in the casing of the spinning reel Mitchell 300Pro.

I lost this cap on my last fishing trip.

To produce the threaded part of the cap, I used the OpenSCAD file
'Nut Job' nut, bolt, washer and threaded rod factory by Mike Thompson 1/12/2013, Thingiverse: mike_linus.

The outer diameter = 10.8 and the thread step = 1.2.

This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/l0Y7x3B4oy0

Alright,

This isn't just a print and go kinda thing here. You'll need to prepare.

You'll need -

1) Nuts and Bolts for attaching the Yoke to the Band.
2) Original STAX SR-Σ (Screws) or Aftermarket.

Print all parts, saw the Nut to the length where it doesn't hinder articulation, I would give exact dimensions and stuff if I had the time but I'm really busy atm.
Once you saw the nut, you can either drill and glue it in the pre designed hole beneath the band, or you can heat fuse it, like I have done.
The Yoke is designed to fit inside the holes without any screws, the Sigma has different diameter holes on either side. This didn't work out for me as the it was very loose, so I cut the ends and drilled a hole for the long screw so I can have the right tension required for a good fit.
That's it.

Things to remember -

1) If you decide to nicely finish off the parts and paint it, please scale the models accordingly. There isn't tolerance for thick coats, the sliders will not work.

2) You need to make a Headband strap, I used Alcantara for mine.

3) Print Yoke in Nylon if you can, ABS required patient assembly or else the top part will crack, depending upon the drill size.

4) Attach the bolt for the side articulation before assembling it into the Sigma, tension according to your wish!

That's all I can remember to say right now, I'll update if I remember something.
Please don't sell these models for profit, I have invested time and money to get these designed and kept them free for a reason.

This page is Work in progress!!!

This is the Base enclosure for a selfmade PoS-Cashier-System with Article-Database, based on the RaspberryPi as CPU.

There are two other missing parts because the used Hardware is not final and a complete change of these parts is possible! They will be uploaded when the used Hardware is final.

There are Two different files. I have made a "slim" version caused on the big baseplate. By reducing the Baseplate to this I was able to reduce my printing time from over 24h to 13h18m!

The project itsself is non-public and will maybe opened to the public later. But you can Download and Tweak the enclosure to Build your own PoS-System. Have Fun!

title: 5-Ago (Modular Stone Placement Game Board)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: This is a modular game board with slots cut out for placing stones or marbles. Iâ€™m sure you could use this with any assorted stone placement game (go, tic-tac-toe, or whatnot). Iâ€™m using this to learn what the friends and I decided to call â€œ5-agoâ€ you can read about the similar commercial game Pentago at http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pentago or http://www.pentago.se/ENRules.pdf

As I intended the stones to stay in place when the board is being moved(a move in Pentago involves rotating a quadrant of the board), they donâ€™t come out easily unless the board is dumped out.  If youâ€™re playing a game where the stones are frequently removed, you should consider modifying them.
I was in a hurry when I printed these so the size is smaller than some people may like.  Scale it up if you see fit.

comments.text: Now to figure out how to put it in tracks like the commerical game and tempt litigation.
comments.author: cymon

comments.text: Yeah, I was trying to avoid any shenanigans with IP stuff.  Thingiverse needs more fully print and play games though.  I'm trying to find other interesting ones that don't require any cards with text or boards with art so I can make some more.

comments.text: It looks nice but please first try to slice all parts without defects before you start printing. Your slicer will probably fail at slicing the wheel parts by creating lots of empty layers. The reason for this is maybe the wheels are just shells with very thin walls where even the thin wall detection of the slicer doesn't work. But thats just an assumption. I already created a lot of plastic waste because I recognized the bugs too late.

Just a simple clip to hold objects using elastics (see the picture)

The clips shown in the picture were printed in PLA, however, if you leave them inside a car during a hot day, they will easily bend. Thus, I suggest print in ABS ;)

The printrbot team working on the hot end decided to take the Microsoft approach, and not make itself backward compatible with existing hot ends... This frustrated the heck out of me, so i designed an adapter so any hot end will fit.
Really printrbot? Come on.

Print this, and install in between the existing mount.
See the skp file for a diagram how it all fits together...
Please feel free to make this design better.
V2.0:  Added slot for 6-32 nut for top mount.  Use 1" 6-32 screw.

comments.text:
Does this work with an E3D Lite hotend ?
Currently I am using a wood adapter in order to mount the Extruder support into the lower hole from the idler, otherwise hotend tip would be higher that the idler lowest point ...
I also made some version of a support, but still need to work on it ... but I also was thinking of an adapter plate like you did .

title: Ieyo Bust - Dual Extrusion Style
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Wow! Introducing the Ieyo Bust for dual extruder 3D printers!

After printing this strange, flamboyant and amazing creature with a single extruder, we decided to make a small modification to add a touch of color to the design!

The original design was made for single extruder printers. We contacted Paul Braddock, the designer of this amazing piece, and he authorized us to publish his design with some modifications for dual-head printers!

Original design by Paul Braddock: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:297846

Check out Paul Braddock designs on his website (http://www.paul-braddock.com/) or his Instagram (https://www.instagram.com/paulbraddock/). This guy is a genius!

Piece on the images printed with the BCN3D Sigma and Colorfila PLA.

You can also follow us through our social media channels in order to get more information about us:

Instagram: https://www.instagram.com/bcn3dtech/
Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/bcn3dtechnologies/

comments.text: STL is Damage !
comments.author: DRAGON1969

comments.text:
Hello Dragon,
The Boo Slott design is perfectly printable and resizable. The design was made in two different 3D programs swapping back and forth has caused some inconsistencies which don't affect the printing result at all. If you would analyze the design in a STL analyzing app or program like MakePrintable you can see that the final print will be perfect of if you like you can 'clean up' the design in accordance with you printer type before printing.
However the file will be perfectly printed when you feed it to an Ultimaker as you can see on the photo where I used red/orange PLA.
Good luck printing and all suggestions are always welcome!!!!

title: Flower shower | Cap for water bottle

description.text:
A watering attachment to adjust it on an already used bottle of water.

DESCRIPTION

A "do it yourself" watering pot, for small and medium sized flower pots.
An "easy to store" product to cover the same need that a large one is used to do. A clever way to keep your place clear from the presence of various objects, which take plenty of space and create confusion around you, use it only when it is needed!
It provides different solutions depending on the needs of each plant or on its bushiness. More precisely, it combines two hoses, a cylindrical hose, to water the plant directly to its base, when the plant is bushy or small, and a regular hose, which could be adjusted to the one mentioned above. So, you have a "2in1" watering pot!
Last but not least, it features an 'air-passage' that allows the air-entry from the exterior environment to the inside of the bottle, so as the liquid comes out quicker and continuous, without causing any deformation on the bottle.

USE

1|Remove the cap of your already used bottle of water.
2|Screw the first part of the 3-d printed watering attachment, like a cap (PCO28, the one widely used in Europe).
3|Adjust the second 3-d printed part, depending on your needs!

Hephestos 2 | BQ

description.text: The ceilings are too low in my house for my height against a ceiling fan. I am constantly getting hit in the head in my kids room and I just needed a little extra space. I was able to use the custom ceiling fan blade bracket to make a spacer to increase the height of the fan blades. I used 1-1/2 inch 10-24 screws to replace the ones that come with the fan and scaled the 3D file to be 32 mm high. Unfortunately the holes didn't line up completely right so I did have to drill new holes but it did the trick. Also had to counter sink the part of the spacer that meets up with the fan blade bracket. I used glow in the dark filament so the kids now have a spinning ceiling night light and love it... and I don't get hit in the head anymore!

Printer Brand:

Robo 3D

Printer:

R1 ABS + PLA Model

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

30

comments.text:
Nice work.
Here's an idea for you. Since the fan blades are now closer to the ceiling, they may push down less air. You could increase the amount they do push by increasing the angle the blades are tilted by making your extensions more wedge shaped, instead of just a straight extrusion. That will also give you a chance to make the holes align better. Or don't. It looks cool like that anyway.
comments.author: smallnetd

comments.text: Good idea, thanks! I will try and compare the amount of air movement between our 2 bedrooms and see if there is a noticeable difference.

Hawaii hotspot

The Hawaii hotspot is a volcanic hotspot located near the namesake Hawaiian Islands, in the northern Pacific Ocean. One of the most well-known and heavily studied hotspots in the world, the Hawaii plume is responsible for the creation of the Hawaiian – Emperor seamount chain, a chain of volcanoes over 5,800 km long. Four of these volcanoes are active, two are dormant, and more than 123 are extinct, many having since been ground beneath the waves by erosion as seamounts and atolls. (Information source: Wiki)

Pythagoras Tree with a side length ratio of 3:4:5. The cubes are intentionally designed to overlap to a little bit for stability. Easy to design in 123D Design using the basic idea of similarity.

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

DIY

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2mm

Infill:

20%
Pythagoras Tree Pythagoras Tree

It is designed in 123D Design, starting with a 25mm^3 cube. Make two copies, scale them using factors 0.6 and 0.8, rotate about 53 and 36 degrees, Once you have the first layer, make copies, scale them down, and iterate ...

This could be a bold artistic statement?

It could be that you don't like wearing your glasses?

Either way - since I printed this - everyone notices. Everyone stops and looks from a distance - then walks up close to see the finely detailed surprises on each of the numbers.

There are lots of styles of large wall-clock motors and hands available on Amazon.com - usually for about $20. They usually come with a guide to help you place the numbers.

Designing the Numbers

I'm still a beginner - and I used Tinkercad.com to make this.

I wanted a cool font, so I chose "Righteous" from Google Fonts.

I traced each number into SVG files, then scaled them to 80mm tall and 5mm thick.

After that I made hundreds of copies of the same number - but only 5mm tall. The hundreds of copies were grouped and turned into holes, then embedded 1mm down into the big number.

The effect is that the numbers sparkle from a distance, but when you get very very close to them you can see the detail.

I like art that can be appreciated from a distance, but surprises up close. This is my little attempt.

About the Font

Righteous was initially inspired by the all capitals letterforms from the deco posters of Hungarian artist Robert Berény for Modiano. Grid based and geometric in execution, the letterforms are highly readable at a range of point sizes. Unlike that of the inspiration source, Righteous has a full lowercase to increase flexibility of use..

description.text:
The goal of this project was to see how much I could simplify the construction of something like this by leveraging modular connectors (the joints). You could assemble this using only a screwdriver and a drill (for pilot holes). You could have all of the wood cut for you (I intentionally had this done at home depot for some of the wood), and the connectors make up for any sloppy cuts. I did cheat a few times by gluing the drawer and mitering the angled pieces.

Connectors fit 1x2 wood. To assemble lower frame, you need:
2x bottom_a_with_wheel_hole
2x bottom_a_with_wheel_hole.flipped
2x bottom_a
2x bottom_a.flipped

To assemble upper frame:
1x bottom_a
1x bottom_a.flipped
1x bottom_b_angle_with_wheel_hole
1x bottom_b_angle_with_wheel_hole.flipped
1x top_b_angle
1x top_b_angle.flipped

Sets of 2x slidebracket, 2x slidebracket.flipped can be used to attach slides to bottom frame.

Sets of 1x anglebracket, 1x anglebracket.flipped can be used to attach platforms to top frame.

You can make the wood any length you'd like, but the dimensions I used are:

Lower frame:
8x 18" for horizontal pieces
4x 24" for vertical pieces

Upper frame:
4x 18"
2x 22"
2x 27.5" (These pieces need to be cut at an angle. It's a 3-4-5 triangle so the angles are: 53.13 and 36.87 degrees)

comments.text: I like this idea! What were your print settings, and how sturdy is this?
comments.author: rocketmannate

comments.text: It's very sturdy, but the screws provide much of the strength. The connectors help keep everything at the proper angle, and make up for any sloppiness in the wood cuts.
comments.author: rocketmannate

title: Hictop Prusa I3 Y-Axis Belt Tensioner

description.text:
I purchased my Prusa I3 printer off of Amazon from Hictop in Feb. 2015. Originally, to adjust the y-axis belt tension required flipping the whole printer on its side and playing with the cable attach points to tighten the belt. That got old very quickly. I saw another similar tensioner, thing # 807702, and I adapted the general design to fit my printer. This design works well and I will be happy if it will help someone else with belt tension issues.
The Axel bolt is 8mm in diameter and the bearing an 8x22x7 bearing. The attach hardware is 3mm machine screws as is the tensioning screw. You will need to drill a new hole for the tensioning screw. Otherwise this assembly is a direct replacement for the original. Y-axis travel is the same but caution should be taken when tightening the belt as too much tension can easily be placed on the belt. The y-axis will not operate properly if there is too much tension and will cause the stepper motor to skip.
To adjust tension, loosen the nut on the 8mm bolt and jam nut (if used) on the tensioning screw. Tighten the tensioning screw checking belt tension by hand. Tighten the 8mm bolt nut and screw jam nut (if used) and test printer operation. I recommend running a calibration test after belt tension.

remixed_from.title: Direct-drive hinged extruder for E3D/J-Head hot-end (Prusa i3)

description.text:
All credit goes to lawsy's original design.  I have modified his mk3 and mk5 in order to create an extruder assembly that can tightly hold the E3D hotend, while still hopefully allowing for a easy removal for maintenance.  It features the filament guide of the mk3, and uses the x-axis endstop feet from his mk5.  I have removed the accessory system that was previously present, because the E3D does not seem to have any room for accessories in this spot.  
Please feel free to remix or make suggestions.  I have not yet received my E3D hotend in order to test it, so please let me know if I need to adjust the fit.  
Edit:  Updated to accommodate for the clearance needed for the Solidoodle 3's carriage.
Assemble similarly to the mk3 and mk5, using M3 bolts.  Additional M3 bolts are required to attach the retainer plate to the front of the extruder assembly.

I created this some time ago, but never released it. This is in the style of the older OpenForge 1.0 stone series (including that it's an "edge" tile), but I've updated it to have support for the OpenForge 2.0 style bases. This piece and the pieces I'll release on friday (the barbican) are actually what inspired me to do the changes I did in OpenForge 2.0, as I couldn't figure out a real good way to add on an additional story to this, and thus the bases were born.

I'll probably eventually replace this with a cut-stone version, but I think these pieces are too awesome to never see the light of day. Having used them in game, along with the rest of the barbican, these got a total wow reaction from players.

Also, this is the first set I'm taking photos of in a lightbox I made with the support I've gotten from my patrons. Let me know if you like the white or black backed pictures better. I think these are much more clear, so I'm prone to move forward with the white backgrounds.

For instructions on how to get started with OpenForge, take a look at our tutorials.

OpenForge is now a patron supported project. I use the resources that my patrons give me in order to get the resources to let me create more sophisticated tiles with a greater level of detail. description.text:
The nRF24L01 radio module I buy comes in two versions, each with a different antenna connector. I don't typically use the version with a built in antenna trace, as I need long distance capability. However, its been found that the modules need shielding to reach longer distances, and some people have found that shielding helps with nearby micro controller operation. I suppose it can even help with FCC certification, assuming that is a thing for you...

So, I know the first thing a DIY'er will do is grab some aluminum foil... but I really like a cleaner look, so I built a "cover" for my radio module. Once you put the module in the cover, you wrap it in foil. I have copper self-adhesive foil all around my house, because of some Stained Glass work I enjoy.. there is no reason to glue the module cover either if you are wrapping it with self-adhesive tape!

It is a tight fit on purpose. I can get mine to fit around the board snugly with some pressure (getting the antenna connector through is the main issue). For a SMA connector, attach it after putting the cover on. And remember, the shield needs to be grounded and sufficient thickness to work the best, from what I can tell. ~1 mil foil is fine probably, and remember you can do multiple layers! In my case I just do a quick solder from the antenna ground to the foil since they are touching.

Material cost: 0.08

I use a .3 layer height and 40% infill, but its so small many printers are going to use 100% infill on a lot of the model anyhow.

Wrap with foil and ground the foil...

Remember for outdoor use, adhesive can fail with prolonged water contact... of course, none of these modules are waterproof either.. so this will help with waterproofing but its not the only action you should take to waterproof.

I included the model I use..

I generally build a simple block model of the part, then build the covering plastic form, and then subtract the model out and adjust. Its easier for me to measure and build a model first, then adjust tolerances on the cover once I have cut away the space the model takes..

Also I use 123dDesign for most of this, as its pretty easy to learn all in all.. and its FREE.

Another hard part blast from the past! Remember those dwell up/down buttons and the cricket board? You was a baller if you had that chirp chirp, son.

Well let's shave some weight off that shoebox and throw a newly contoured, 3D Printed tray on it! Get weird with it, remix this bad boy, and lets keep the old school gats going a bit.

This shouldn't be...AS dangerous as the bolt, but still, I take no responsibility of this thing goes south and breaks during a game.

Work in Progress

I have been designing this printer for the better part of half a year now. This printer is designed to have a built in activated carbon HEPA air scrubber as well as a full enclosure in order to protect ABS prints against drafts. (also, to scrub out all the air of the nasty VOCs that ABS releases).

If you're interested in seeing how this printer turns out, I will keep posting parts and updates to this. I have finished 90% of the hardware design and I have mostly moved on to testing my electronics.

EVERY SINGLE PRINTED PART WILL BE PRINTABLE WITHOUT SUPPORTS. Why? Because f#ck removing supports. They mar the surface of the print and are almost always generated in excess. My parts will have all their supports built in, which is what you may notice when looking at the parts as they have all been uploaded in their printing orientation. Before undertaking this, I suggest you perform a test print to see how decently your printer can bridge. If you can do at least a 5mm bridge, then you'll be able to print these parts :)

This design will take advantage of my fume scrubber....The VOC Eater!
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1781164

*Update
9/29/2016

The mechanical design is basically completed. The only thing I'm doing now is looking at all my parts and trying to cut back on the volume of filament used in each part. I'm also printing like mad, lol.

*Update
10/20/2016

Having a slight slow to progress. My current printer's extruder is acting funky and I have to fix it before continuing the process of "print, measure, re-design, and repeat". I have however, not stopped tweaking the design.

I've had two 3d printers up to this point. The first being a QU-BD 1up, the second (and current) is a Folgertech prusa i3, although you would think it's something else thanks to all the changes I've made to it. Each printer had it's own fault, so I decided to stop complaining and see if I can do better.

I wanted a printer will at least approximately 350x350x350 build volume. I wanted it to have a heated bed that can RAPIDLY heat, I wanted strong stepper motors that could potentially do light cnc work (Maybe...a guy can dream), I wanted a printer controller that i'd never need to upgrade from...and didn't suck cough china ramps board cough, and I wanted it to be enclosed so I can manage those disgusting fumes from ABS. I also wanted it to be autonomous from my computer.

These are the materials needed to build the frame of the printer. Electronics are subject to your own personal tastes of course (example: you could use a RAMBO/RAMPs/Smoothieboard for your controller) but I will add this info at a later date for what I used.

The following can all be found at www.openbuildspartstore.com Aluminum v-slot extrusions. All are 500mm in length.
8 - 20x80mm
2 - 20x60mm
7 - 20x40mm
4 - 20x20mm 2 - Nut plates for 8mm Metric Acme Lead Screw
2 - 5mm x 8mm Flexible Coupling
24 - Slot Cover/Panel Holder's
2 - 8mm diameter Acme Lead Screw, 500mm in length
4 - NEMA 17 stepper motors (Or stepper motors of equivalent dimensions).
20 - Solid V wheel kits 6 - Smooth Idler Pulley Wheel Kit
12 - 15mm Low profile M5 screws
16 - 50mm Low profile M5 screws
175 - 10mm Low profile M5 screws (it's actually 162, but open builds sells them in packages of 25)
175 - Tee Nuts

The following materials that were sourced from various other places on the web. I will associate parts to websites when I get a moment to sit down and back track. 40 - 10mm M3 screws. www.amazon.com
2 - 688Z Metal Sealed Deep Grove Radial Ball Bearings 8 x 16 x 5mm www.amazon.com
2 - Black Plastic Drag Chain Cable Carrier 10 x 15mm for CNC Router Mill www.amazon.com
50pcs M3*4mm H62 Brass Knurl Nuts DIY Accessories Shipped and Sold www.amazon.com(can't buy individuals) 350mm x 350mm 800W silicone heating mat. I ordered mine from http://www.keenovo.com/index.html 380mm x 380mm Borosilicate glass plate. Got mine from the https://www.voxelfactory.com/ but I'm wondering now if they still offer that service. I'm very happy with the work they did though.
(more to follow)

comments.text: Looking at your design and others... I have yet to see one that I would consider building myself as motors and electronics work best over time when they are kept cool. If the motors electronics and belts are moved to the outside, the inside could easily be heated to 100 C without any problems. Wires going to the heating elements would just need to be a bit bigger, and some material that is good for 200+ C, and then all of the shrinkage might be able to be eliminated. I was going to try this, but I am short on money at the moment.
